text: <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells orchestrate the Th1-type cell - mediated immune response in RA [ 22 ] .

Activated <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells stimulate macrophages , synovial fibroblasts , B cells , and osteoclasts through the expression of cell surface molecules and Th1 cytokines , thereby contributing to both the chronic inflammation and the joint destruction .

<extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells require two signals to be activated ; antigen receptor occupancy and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated costimulation .

In the ST lesion , the <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ligands , both <extra_id_0> CD80 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CD86 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , together with MHC class II antigens , are substantially expressed by antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells [ 18-20 ] .

The significance of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> engagement in the T-cell - mediated disease process has recently been proven by the clinical efficacy of its blocker <extra_id_0> cytotoxic T-cell-associated antigen 4 (CD152)-IgG <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in RA patients [ 23 ] .
<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays a predominant role in limiting immune and inflammatory responses by regulating the function of both macrophages and Th1 cells [ 1 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits the tyrosine phosphorylation of the <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule and the subsequent phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase binding in T cells , and thereby directly acts on T cells [ 24 ] .

In the present study , we found that PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from patients with active RA , in the presence of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , are able to produce higher levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> after CD3 and <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> costimulation than normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

Despite high - level <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and constitutive <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced tyrosine phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is suppressed in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , in contrast to normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , where <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation is dose-dependently inducible by <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Serum <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from RA patients induces <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but not <extra_id_0> STAT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation in normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , and exogenous <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces the resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production .

RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells contain higher levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but contain lower levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcripts in comparison with normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

These findings indicate that <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells become resistant to the inhibitory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> before migration into the inflamed ST , and suggest that this resistance may be attributable to impaired <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , in association with sustained <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation and <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction .

<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated inhibition of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T-cell cytokine production is principally dependent on its inhibition of macrophage antigen-presenting cell function [ 1 ] .

However , this indirect inhibitory effect is thought to be restricted at the site of T-cell activation in RA , because macrophages in the ST express high levels of cytokines , <extra_id_0> CD80 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> CD86 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecules , and MHC class II antigens [ 10 , 18-20 ] .

More recently , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been shown to induce the antigen - specific T-cell unresponsiveness by inhibiting <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> tyrosine phosphorylation [ 33 ] .

This direct effect also may be limited in active RA patients , because their PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells showed a defective <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - costimulated production of both <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Numerous cytokines , both proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory , have been detected in the ST of RA , and the balance between these opposing cytokine activities regulates disease severity [ 10 ] .
Endogenous <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , produced mainly by macrophages and T cells , inhibits proinflammatory cytokine production by ST cells [ 12 ] .
However , this regulatory activity seems to be restricted during chronic inflammation .

The activation of both the extracellular stimulus - regulated kinase and p38 kinase pathways , induced by <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , inhibits the <extra_id_0> Jak1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling pathway shared by <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in adhered macrophages [ 13 ] .
More importantly , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation is mostly undetectable in RA synovial macrophages .

This impaired <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling is probably induced by chronic exposure to immune complexes in vivo , because both cell surface <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> Jak1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation are suppressed in <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - primed macrophages by a protein kinase C - dependent pathway following ligation of the IgG Fc gamma receptor [ 14 ] .

Furthermore , dendritic cells from RA synovial fluids are resistant to the immunoregulatory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> due to decreased transport of intracellular <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of proinflammatory cytokine stimuli such as <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 15 ] .

We have demonstrated that the resistance of RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be associated with defective <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , but not with <extra_id_0> IL-10R1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

Inhibitory effects of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on these inflammatory cell types are therefore differentially modulated at the signal transduction level under the inflammatory environment in RA .

In association with impaired <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found to be tyrosine phosphorylated persistently ( up to 6 hours ) in freshly isolated PB and ST <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from RA patients .

<extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is activated by a variety of cytokines , notably the IL-6 family of cytokines ( e.g . <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-11 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> leukemia inhibitory factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> oncostatin M <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and growth factors , in addition to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 4 ] .

Of these cytokines , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> plays a predominant role in eliciting a systemic reaction such as the acute phase response in active RA , due mainly to its abundance in the blood circulation [ 27 ] .

Consistent with this notion , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was the major <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activating factor contained in the serum of active RA patients , and the responsiveness to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was suppressed in normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells after 36 hours of incubation with <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

These results suggest that both the sustained <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation and the resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition found in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells may be induced after chronic exposure in vivo to high concentrations of serum <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

However , it is also possible that <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity could be constitutively induced in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells by their own <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion , leading to the loss of sensitivity to exogenous <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , because RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells in the ST are capable of producing significant levels of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 34 ] .

<extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells isolated from the ST of RA also showed a defect in the <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling pathway .

It is most probable that the resistance of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can be even augmented after migration into the inflamed ST , because <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is highly concentrated compared with the blood level [ 27 ] .

In addition , the involvement of other essential proinflammatory cytokines in this process was suggested by our preliminary experiments demonstrating that <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells was reduced by pretreatment with <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , although less effectively than by <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( data not shown ) .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> produced by <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells themselves could be responsible for impaired <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling in the ST , because T-cell infiltrates produce both cytokines [ 34 , 35 ] .

In an autocrine fashion , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may persistently stimulate <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation and <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can induce <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein as a crosstalk inhibitor of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling [ 32 ] .

The T-cell - inhibitory effect of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may therefore be modulated complicatedly upon exposure to an inflammatory environment in RA joints , where many cytokines are present substantially [ 10 ] .
<extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation has been implicated in the pathogenesis of RA .
Active <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is constitutively expressed in synovial fluid mononuclear cells from RA patients [ 36 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the major <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activating factor present in synovial fluid , which has a crucial role in the activation of monocyte functions such as gene expression of the <extra_id_0> Fc gamma receptor type I <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> type III <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and of HLA-DR [ 31 ] .

More recently , high levels of activated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , thought to be induced mainly by <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , have been detected in the ST , and <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation has been shown to be involved in synovial fibroblast proliferation and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production [ 37 ] .
In this regard , <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is critical in the survival and expansion of growth factor - dependent synovial fibroblasts [ 38 ] .

Furthermore , the significance of persistent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling in Th1-cell-dominated autoimmune arthritis has been suggested by studies of the <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> F759 / F759 mice , in which the Src homology phosphatase-2 binding site of <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( the <extra_id_0> transmembrane glycoprotein beta subunit of the IL-6 family cytokine receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , tyrosine 759 , was mutated to phenylalanine [ 39 ] .

In the <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> F759 / F759 mice , T cells , particularly the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T-cell subset , are chronically activated and resistant to activation - induced cell death through <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .
The longevity of cytokine signals transduced by the JAK-STAT pathway is regulated by the SOCS family proteins [ 7 ] .

We found that <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from patients with active RA expressed higher levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but lower levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , compared with normal <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> prevents activation of JAK by directly binding to JAK , and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits the action of JAK by binding to the Src homology phosphatase-2 - binding domain of receptors such as <extra_id_0> gp130 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 40 ] .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are induced by various cytokines , including <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as mediators of negative feedback and crosstalk inhibition [ 7 ] .

Recent studies with mice lacking <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> revealed that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a negative regulator of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling but not of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling .

Studies of conditional <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient mice have shown that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiency , but not <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiency , results in sustained activation of <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in response to <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 8 , 41 ] .

The analysis of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient macrophages has indicated that <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a crucial inhibitor of the <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced transcriptional response [ 42 ] .

However , <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is dispensable for both the negative feedback inhibition and the immunoregulatory action of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in macrophages [ 41 ] .
On the contrary , <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found to directly inhibit <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated signaling [ 43 ] .

Increased <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in RA <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells may therefore be associated with both the impaired responsiveness to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , and defective <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression may be responsible for persistent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation in response to serum <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

There is a possibility that <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction may be associated with the ability of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells to produce <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , because <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA could produce high levels of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the presence of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and because <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been known as a potent inducer of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 32 ] .

It is of interest in this regard to indicate that polarized Th1 and Th2 cells express high levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , respectively [ 44 ] .

<extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation is inhibited by <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction in Th2 cells , whereas <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> STAT6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling is diminished by <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction in Th1 cells .

<extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may thus have important roles as Th1 - specific and Th2 - specific , mutually exclusive , cross-talk repressors of the <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> STAT6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> STAT4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling pathways , respectively .

Consistent with this notion , PB T cells from patients with allergic diseases significantly express high levels of <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcripts , and the <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression correlates well with serum IgE levels and disease pathology [ 45 ] .

Higher <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression with lower <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in PB <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from RA patients , compared with healthy controls , is therefore probably consistent with their systemic bias towards a Th1 phenotype , as has previously been demonstrated [ 46-49 ] .
